slides.title: Acid‑Base Definitions (Arrhenius & Brønsted‑Lowry)
slides.html_body:
Acid‑Base Definitions

Arrhenius acids increase [H⁺] in water; Brønsted‑Lowry acids donate protons.

slides.title: pH, pOH, and the pH Scale
slides.html_body:
pH and pOH

pH = -log[H⁺]; pOH = -log[OH⁻]; pH + pOH = 14 at 25 °C.

slides.title: Strong vs. Weak Acids and Bases
slides.html_body:
Strength of Acids/Bases

Strong acids/bases dissociate completely; weak acids/bases only partially dissociate.

slides.title: Acid‑Base Neutralization Reactions
slides.html_body:
Neutralization

Acid + Base → Salt + Water. Example: HCl + NaOH → NaCl + H₂O.

slides.title: Titration Curves and Endpoint Detection
slides.html_body:
Titration Curves

Visualize pH change as titrant is added; the equivalence point is where moles acid = moles base.

slides.title: Buffer Solutions and Henderson‑Hasselbalch
slides.html_body:
Buffers

Buffers resist pH change. pH = pKa + log([A⁻]/[HA]).

slides.title: Calculating Concentrations in Acid‑Base Solutions
slides.html_body:
Concentration Calculations

Use dilution and stoichiometry to find unknown concentrations.

slides.title: Real‑World Applications
slides.html_body:
Applications

Acid‑base chemistry in medicine, industry, and environmental science.
